p: Acacia nilotica (L.) Delile sub nilotica (Leguminosae) is a tree found in the central and northern parts of Sudan and is known in Sudanese folk medicine by the common name ‘Garad or Sunt.’ The fruit and the stem bark are regarded as a tonic and astringent and are used internally to treat colds, bronchitis, pneumonia, diarrhea, and dysentery [ 14, 15]. Fractionation of A. nilotica leaves and bark showed the presence of phenols condensed tannin [ 16], gallic acid, (+) catechin, (−) epigallocatechin-7-g’allate, catechin derivatives [ 17, 18], ellagic acid, kaempferol, and quercetin [ 19]. Parallelly many researches demonstrated its wide array of pharmacological activities, such as anti- HIV-1 protease [ 20], antibacterial [ 21], antioxidant, anticarcinogenic [ 22, 23] and anti-inflammatory activities [ 24]. In Sudanese and Indian traditional medicine, gargle the decoction of the A. nilotica bark is used to strengthens teeth and eliminates toothache [ 25– 27]. Even though there is a little investigation on the potential beneficial effects of A. nilotica bark on oral health. Thus, we evaluated the effects of A. nilotica bark methanolic extract and its fractions on the growth of two oral bacteria included S. sobrinus and P. gingivalis. We also investigated their GTF inhibitory activity and antioxidant functions for oral hygiene purposes.
